Questions: Do pro-choice people see fetuses as human beings? Why or why not?
Answers:
I spent 5 years getting and being pregnant. Only one pregnancy resulted in a living child. My son is now 15. The others all died on their own or were terminated at the hospital, sometimes violently, nearly taking me with them (2 ectopic), all tragically.

Each and every one of those pregnancies were planned and desperately wanted. To me, each one was my baby. To me, each was a potential human being.

I was willing to risk my own death for potential life by repeatedly getting pregnant, but was completely unwilling to accept that same risk once there was no longer a viable potential life inside me. That is why I have one living biological child, one adopted child, and five more that never made it to the world.

As a woman…as a human…I don’t care when life begins, or when an embryo becomes a fetus, or when a fetus becomes a baby during a pregnancy. Living humans are allowed to decide how they want to use their own bodies and their own internal organs. They are allowed to decide when or if they are willing to sacrifice themselves for another. This is not a public decision. It is a personal decision.

Every child should be born wanted. And every woman who sacrifices her body to grow a baby, should be a parent by choice, not by force. I am uncompromising on this. Anything less is a breach of human rights. Anything less is a form of slavery.

Questions: Given an option, which country will you move to and why?
Answers:
Thanks for asking — but I would just settle in India, even though I could practically move to any country I want.

US is probably the one country outside of India I loved the most. I had the chance to get a US greencard — my colleagues and classmates from India have become citizens by now — but I have declined to even apply. I dodged the bullet everytime my paralegal at Microsoft pushed me those forms to sign.

I could have had a PR from Canada or many of the European countries. I love visiting those countries and doing business there, but not considered settling. Middle eastern countries like UAE also don’t interest me as a place to settle, just as a place to setup subsidiary business.

I fly thrice a week and out of the country every month — but India is where I would love to come back every time. Not because of family or friends (I have more family and friends outside India than inside), ageing parents or a family business to take. I have none of those issues. Not because I hated the US — I love it.

We have a historic opportunity to get India out of its temporary state of poverty. That challenge looks an amazing thing to solve. As an engineer I want to solve toughest problems, as an entrepreneur I want to take the biggest markets and as an amateur historian I want to be on the history books. In short, India is the place to be.

Questions: Has Narendra Modi successfully polarised Hindu votes?
Answers:
Let me illustrate the whole story with the help of Fair & Lovely.

Fair & Lovely was launched in 1975 by Hindustan Unilever. Unfortunately, this product was only for females. Males who wanted to look fair had no other option. Some used to manage their urges by using this female product. This is how 30 years passed.

Emami noticed the domination of Fair & Lovely in Indian market. However, it realised that nearly 50% of the market, that is male gender, is left untargeted. So in 2005, Emami introduced Fair & Handsome, for men. They started discouraging men using female fairness creams via ads. In the end, they captured the market easily.

Now tell me, did Emami polarise the market? Maybe a little. However, actual polarisation began in 1975 when only female gender was targetted.

Similarly, in politics, the actual polarisation began on the day when separate laws were drafted for Muslims. BJP has just targeted a community that was not targeted by anybody.

If Congress had taken care of Hindu interests also, then there would have been no scope for Modi to rise. Modi would have been in Gujarat.

In short, the seeds of Hindutva were actually sown by Congress. RSS, VHP and BJP have only watered it.

Questions: What is wrong with our society today?
Answers:
A few months back, I was in a beauty salon getting my eyebrows shaped.

Two girls enter and make themselves comfortable there and try to decide the service they could take.

A few minutes later, someone called them from outside. He was an autorickshaw driver.

He complained to them about giving him a critically torn 500 Rupee note.

They tried to convince him a lot. He didn't agree.

They asked him to take on some other day. But he didn't agree. How could he possibly have known where they lived? Even if he did, it was fair on his part.

It was merely 30 Rupees.

They got angry with him and started to taunt.

They didn't understand one thing. It was his work, time and money. If that note didn't work out, he might lose 500 Rupees plus his precious time.

500 is a big thing for an auto driver.

Now comes the funniest part.

They asked the salon owner for 30 Rupees and paid the driver and paid the owner through paytm since owner didn't take the 500 Rupees note either.

Suddenly one of the girl asked, “Aunty please batao is note ko kaise chala sakte h?”

(Aunty how can we use this useless 500 Rupee note?)

Aunty replied, “Beta ek kaam karo, ye note muje de do. Mere husband bank me kaam karte hai. Notes ki gaddio k beech me kahi daal denge, pata bhi nahi chalega”.

(Dear, give this note to me and my husband who works in a bank will make sure to slide this useless note in the note bundles)

I was shocked to hear that.

Do you get what's wrong with our society?

Most of us don't like to face problems but create one for others and think, “Wo ab uski problem hai, wo dekhe”.

(It's his problem now, he will sort it out)

She could have taken the effort to go to the bank and get the note exchanged but she wanted to get rid of her problem at the cost of making it someone else's problem.

Nobody wants to solve anything in a decent way because we don't want to worry about it and waste our time.

This was just one example. There are several.

-Smita

Questions: In one word, what is wrong with today's society?
Answers:
Immediacy.

Click to watch your favorite show. Swipe right for a date. Have Amazon deliver your object of desire in a day, maybe even this same afternoon. Ask your phone where to eat. Google your question. Post your photo for instant likes. Submit your answer for instant upvotes.

We want it now and if it takes more than a moment we get restless, agitated.

And even though we can get almost anything immediately, most of us are dissatisfied, discontent.

We have more friends than ever and yet we’ve never felt so lonely.

We have more freedom and choices than at any other point in history and yet we’ve never been so confused.

We get more value than any other generation and yet so many of us feel worthless.

We have, to a great extent, lost those most virtuous of qualities… patience, forbearance, equanimity.

We’ve sold them for that false, glittering deity of instant gratification.

But fulfillment, like a slow-growing plant, takes time to cultivate.

You can’t “Buy Now” peace. You can’t swipe for love. You can’t post for self-worth.

Google won’t answer the deepest questions in your heart. Nor Quora.

You’ll have to do some digging for that.

And digging takes time.

Questions: Why did PM Narendra Modi say ‘Jai Siya Ram’, not “Jai Shri Ram”?
Answers:
As a child we used to write thousands of “Shri Rama Jayam” — this is a popular way of Bhakti in Tamil Nadu. Then Sankaracharya told us to rewrite this slogan as “Sita Rama Jayam”. The rationale is that adding Sita to Rama brings a closure and a calmness.

There is the warrior Ram, there is the leader Ram and there is the husband Ram. As a warrior, Ram is an invincible one. He can be aggressive and slay anything on his way. Especially without Sita, his sorrow increases his power & aggression.

The slogan “Jai Shri Ram” made sense during the war to secure the holy land. There were posters across the country with Ram in the warrior pose.

Now that the war is won, it is time to bring Sita back and get Ram from his aggressive stance to his divine grace.

That is the significance of PM Modi using “Jai Siya Ram” instead of “Jai Shri Ram”. It indicates a closure to the struggle that went for centuries.

Questions: What are some of the costliest mistakes ever made in history?
Answers:
The time when a harmless Microsoft office font forced a Prime minister of a country to resign.

In 2015, an anonymous source leaked 11.5 million financial documents from law firm and corporate service provider company Mossack Fonseca. This leak is known as Panama Papers.

The leak reveals that high profile politicians across the globe, including 12 national leaders are buying overseas assets for illegal purposes, including fraud, tax evasion, and evading international sanctions.

Not only that, it was also found that the families and close associates of the politicians are also exploiting the system and evading tax using offshore tax havens.

Countries with politicians, public officials or close associates implicated in the leak (image courtesy: Wikipedia)

Pakistani prime minister Nawaz Sharif was one of the accused in the leak.

Panama leak connected Nawaz Sharif with two objectionable properties in London.

When the case went to Pakistani supreme court, Nawaz Sharif’s daughter Maryam Nawaz submitted two documents in the court. The documents were dated back to 2006 and they were supposed to prove that Sharif’s family has nothing to do with the properties in London.

The blunder:

The documents submitted to the team dated to 2006, but were written in Calibri, a font that was not commercially available before January 31, 2007.

Microsoft word used Times New Roman font as the default font before 2007. From Office 2007 and onwards Calibri was made the default font for Microsoft Word.

This proved that the documents submitted by Sharif’s family were fake and forged.

There were also other evidences against Sharif, but the font blunder significantly weakened his case in Pakistan supreme court.

Sharif’s family lost the case and On 28 July 2017, Sharif was disqualified for public office by the Supreme Court of Pakistan. Sharif submitted his resignation on the following day.

A simple Microsoft word font changed a government!

Bonus fun fact:

Calibri is a Sans-Serif font. or you can call it Sans-Sharif now ;-)

Update:

Some friends are asking what a sans-serif font is. In typography, a “Serif” is the extended edges of an alphabet. The below image can demonstrate it better.

“Sans” means “without”. A font which does not have the Serifs are sans serif fonts.

Times New Roman is a serif font. Calibri is a sans-serif font.

The font which Quora uses is Tiempos Text, and it is also a serif font. Serif fonts are easier for readability. This is why Amazon uses a serif font called Bookerly in Kindle ebook readers.

On the other hand Facebook, Twitter and most other sites use sans-serif fonts. Wikipedia uses Serif font for the article title only, and the content of the article is in sans-serif fonts.

Edit -

He was actually not disqualified because of the font issue, but due to holding a public office during his tenure as prime minister.

Sources:

Panama Papers - Wikipedia

Its a baby Girl!

We were in the operation theatre today to watch the first Caesarian section delivery of our career!

After completing the formalities, the operation finally began. All the steps were being operated smoothly.

Meanwhile I promised my colleague standing by my side that I will throw a treat if its a girl child! :)

The first cry of the baby was the best music I have heard in my entire life!

“Welcome to this world champ”, we wished her.

Yes, this is indeed what's wrong with our society today.

How is this a hard decision?

Questions: How do pro-choice people respond to the question "What if your mom had aborted you?"
Answers:
I know the answer to this one.

If my mother had aborted me, she would have completed her Master’s degree, and got a much better job than what she currently has.

I have fairly young parents. My father and mother got married when they were 23 and 21 respectively. My father got a great job very young, he was ‘settled and ready to get married’ by Indian standards, and he was smitten when he met my mother. At that time my mother had just completed her Bachelor’s degree and agreed to get married, on a condition that my father should be supportive about her studying more.

She went on to get a second Bachelor’s degree in Education. She was 23 and working her way through a Master’s degree when she was pregnant with me. And thanks to me, she was not able to complete her program. We often joke in our house that instead of getting an M.A., she got to be an Amma (Mother).

So to answer the question, I’m sure my mother would have been better off if she aborted me.

I fail to understand what this question has to do with pro-choice philosophy though. First of all, you wouldn’t exist to complain if you were aborted. And who wants to be born if they would have caused physical or psychological harm to their mother?

Questions: In other countries with socialized healthcare, why are they comfortable with the government managing their healthcare? The government shouldn’t be responsible (or trusted) to provide healthcare for its people.
Answers:
My wife is worried about melanoma. We pay a private clinic $209.00 once a year to map her whole body for suspicious moles etc. We do this because it is a dedicated expert service, and takes pressure off the GP system. This year they found one.

Off to the doctor, who agreed to whip it off that afternoon. So a 15m consultation, 30 minute operation, nurse assisting, etc. Total cost $12. The excised flesh was sent to a diagnostic lab for analysis. Unfortunately positive. Total cost $0. Doctor called, said a referral to a specialist surgeon was needed.

This took place the following week: 30 minute consultation, further surgery was scheduled. Total cost $6.00 for parking.

Although the surgery was deemed a priority, it was 2 weeks before it was scheduled as it had to be coordinated between plastic surgeons, radiologists, and overnight bed availability. On the day of surgery, there was an hour’s scanning to locate lymph nodes, then 4 hour’s surgery to remove a larger area around the melanoma, plus 4 lymph nodes, followed by an overnight stay on a ward in a private room. We met with two surgeons, the anaesthetist, nurse assisting, plus others before the operation. Total cost $13.00 for parking, plus $17.50 for lunch for me.

The next day she was discharged, total cost $3.00 for parking.

Two days after, we visited the District Nurse for a dressing change, unfortunately due to the nature of the surgery she was unable to lift her arm high enough and was sent to the Emergency Department so anaesthetic could be administered. For various reasons this turned into a 9 hour saga. Total cost: $0.00.

Today the District Nurse visited us at home to check there were no further problems (and there weren’t). Total cost: $0.00

A further 2 nurse visits are scheduled, total cost $0.00

A follow up surgeon’s consultation is scheduled in 3 weeks, total cost $0.00

No government or bureaucrats in sight, all decisions made by doctors, surgeons, nurses or wife.

No worries about insurance companies, co-payment, loans, mortgages, or finding money for food.

Why can’t all healthcare be this easy?

Questions: What is the main cause of corruption in India?
Answers:
One common question I faced when I was serving in the IPS was, “Why is there so much corruption in government/police?”

Let me start by asking you a question. Imagine you are building a power plant or constructing a high-rise building (say in Mumbai). You have put in all the applications to get the government approval, but you don’t bribe anyone or put any pressure, and just follow the process.

How long will it take to get all the approvals?

One month? One year? 5 years?

Call me a cynic, but I think there is a good chance it won’t happen in your lifetime. You will need approval of 20–25 departments, and you may not even have heard of some of them.

The bureaucracy’s real power is the power to obstruct. This brute power to wreak havoc in lives of citizens is the one of the root causes of corruption in India.

Let us dig deeper.

Our red tape ridden government machinery has evolved from the Licence Permit Raj, a monstrous life sucking machine, even if well intentioned. Here is how it works.
If you need anything done, you need approval from every department on the planet, even if the relevance maybe in one in a million cases. Revenue, fire-force, police, pollution control, environment… the list goes on. Everyone has to say yes. And they can take as much time as they want.
Since there are so many laws and rules, a babu can block things for hundred different reasons. Nobody is fully sure about things.
See below a report in Wall Street Journal, where we are top of the charts in red tape.
Here is an example: Now, say you need approval from 20 government departments. In each department, say 5 people go through your file. While none of them can say yes, each can put an obstacle. So you are facing 100 guys who can stop your dream project.
Unless each of those 100 guys is sensible and honest, your approval is in trouble. And trust me, you will be in trouble.
I will give you an example. In 2005 I was SP Security and I came across a file in which a resort owner had asked for permission of use of wireless walkie-talkie for coordination among staff in a resort near Kerala-Tamil Nadu border. Our Special Branch head-constable reported that there may be LTTE sympathisers in that area who could snatch the walkie-talkie sets and use it for illegal purposes. By this logic, no technology can be used by anyone since everything can be misused. This file was stuck for years because of this.
In short, everybody can block you. So nothing moves, unless you pay up. As they say, “Nothing is allowed, but everything is possible.”
Another important point is that not everybody is corrupt. In Kerala, most IAS and IPS officers are honest. Even lower down, there is a mix of honest and corrupt guys. But even an honest officer will not be able to stop others from corrupt activities, when so much negative power is vested in them. We have a deadwood of a system.
Why are our corruption scandals typically 100–1000 times larger than than those in rich countries like US, France, or Israel?
What is the scandal involving Israeli PM and his wife? $100,000 (Rs 75 lacs). And that is for ordering free food! You will get beaten up if you offer such minuscule bribe to even a low level political functionary in India.
Such massive corruption is not possible without blessings and support of the political class at the top.
Why is the political class so corrupt? Is it just bad people? No, there are deeper reasons.
Political parties need money to operate. And that money has to come from somewhere.
Let us say a party organizes a dharna or rally for which 10,000 people have to be brought. You will have to spend on marketing (loudspeaker announcements, house visits), food, transportation, and in some cases liquor. Assuming Rs 500 per person, the cost of a 10,000 person rally is Rs 50 lacs. I suspect it is even higher.
Each party is running an army of workers and a massive machinery, which has to be well-oiled.
Election campaigns: Crores are needed to fight each parliamentary seat. We have not even talked about the horsetrading and things like that.
Where does that money come from? Donations cover it to an extent. But it is often not nearly enough. Rest comes from contracts, government appointments, purchases, roads and infra, government schemes, licenses and approvals, you name it...
What about political party workers?
How much salary do they get? Maybe a few thousand rupees. Do they live on bread and water? No.
While some are ideologically motivated, many become corrupt over time. Why would they come to your rallies and stand in hot sun, throw stones, and get beaten up by police? How do you compensate them?
Senior guys get perks like Chairmanship of PSUs or other positions, where they can make money. Other guys just use their influence and act as middlemen for everything. From contracts, transfers, recruitments, and peddling favours, they make money.
In essence, if you are an honest politician, your followers will be poor and unhappy. I have seen honest politicians struggle to stay relevant.
Indian government spends a lot. Too much money to be siphoned off. Too many schemes, too many projects. Look at fodder scam. I am not even getting into all the ‘spending for the poor’.
Before we blame the politicians and wash off our hands, just wait. What about rest of us?
Do we attach any social stigma to corruption? Let us say, if a guy is accused of double murder, he may find it difficult to get a bride for his son. But if he has piled up hundred crores through corruption, there is absolutely no such problem. He will have a queue of people lined up.
Even though we rail against corruption, we elect corrupt politicians. We want our neighbour to be honest and all laws applied to him. With ourselves, we are much more lenient.
The reality is, ‘corrupt is the new smart’. The corrupt guy is the ‘practical guy’.
Enforcement is poor because investigation and prosecution is also done by the people who come from the same society.
It is like trying to wash dirt on your white shirt with muddy water. Good luck with that!
Also, the prosecution process and evidence required is very complicated. Even God would not be able to get most cases convicted.

We don’t have universal healthcare or education, but we do have universal corruption. Decentralized, and democratized.

The way we all complain against corruption, it looks like it is perpetrated by aliens. It is as if our politicians were imposed on us by the British. Really?

We have built this country. We own it. And we are responsible for all the good and evil around us. If not through complicity, through our silence. The shame is ours. The blame is ours. This mess we are gifting to our children, is ours.

No amount of waving of national flag, no amount of donation to temples and churches, no amount of blaming politicians will wash this stain.

There has been way too much slogan shouting in public. What matters is what we do in our private lives.

Are we going to do something about it?

Questions: What was the most ridiculous accusation to come out of the #MeToo movement?
Answers:
It has got to be the accusation against legendary singer-songwriter Bob Dylan. A woman alleged he had sexually abused her when she was just a teenager and Dylan in his early twenties. She gave a time and location for when the assault took place, and people got mighty worked up over the whole thing.

People were preparing their pitchforks, media got their panties in a bunch, surely some tabloids were smelling blood! Can we still listen to his songs, do we need to petition radio stations to stop playing them? You know, the usual questions one needs to confront when a legendary icon falls out of favor with the world. Do we cancel the man, do we cancel the art of the man, how can we best erase his entire existence from the face of the earth?

I was a bit scared for a moment. Like, legit ‘heart jumping up in my chest’ levels of scared, because to see Bob Dylan getting accused of something so heinous is rough. He’s a man I admire. The injustice of it also struck me… why on earth is there anyone alive today who would ‘cancel’ Dylan, in a world that has failed to cancel the likes of Andy Dick?[1]

Then, finally, words of relief came! Wisely and in typical Bob Dylan fashion, he did not immediately reply. He likes to leave people guessing a bit; like when he won a Nobel Prize for literature and sort of just… ignored the whole thing, for a while. When he did decide to finally dignify the accusation with a response? The whole story instantly died… because at the time of the supposed assault, Bob Dylan was not in the same country as the alleged victim, who claims the indecent attack happened in her parental home in America.

Bob Dylan had been in England, the girl in America. He was filming a documentary, for which he was being filmed pretty much 24/7. Rock solid alibi. Bob Dylan was lucky enough to avoid cancellation, or worse. And the world is a better place for it.

Questions: What is wrong with our society today?
Answers:
I got suspended from school until August on Tuesday. Now, you’re probably thinking, damn they fucked up, or they must be a bad kid.

Nope. I maintain passing grades, I may not be a genius, but I’m passing all of my classes with a B or a C. I wasn’t rude to a teacher, I didn’t get into any fights, I did nothing wrong that should be considered wrong.

Now, do you want to hear why I was suspended?

I went to my friends for help when I was feeling suicidal and was scared of my mom.

Yup. That’s right.

I asked for help, and got punished for it.

My mom is abusive, both emotionally and physically. She calls me worthless, tells me I shouldn’t exist, and hits me regularly. Because of this, I have some pretty fun anxiety attacks and some odd triggers, such as people moving quickly around me, doors opening unexpectedly, and loud noises when I am asleep.

I have some pretty fucking great friends. They’ve let me sleep on them during our free periods, they bring me food because my mom doesn’t like to feed me. And they comfort me when I have anxiety attacks or am feeling suicidal.

Recently, my mother’s abuse got worse, and they got more worried, and, being the wonderful, amazing, caring people they are, they told adults. January of this year, the first CPS report was filed.

I was called a liar by my mother, and CPS went along with it, as did the Police.

A second report was filed in February, which was again ignored due to my mothers insistence that I was lying. But this time, we had photos, and when the report was filed, I had a bruise on my face.

My mom said the bruise was fake, just make up (even though it clearly wasn’t), and all of my photos were fakes.

Again, I was called a liar and my claims were dismissed.

About a week ago, a third report was filed.

This time, my friends refused to allow it to go unanswered. They’ve made phone calls, talked to so many people, teachers, everyone.

Two weeks ago, I attempted suicide and was taken to the Crisis Center. Not by my mother. She actually tried to turn the police away when my friend got his mom to call in a welfare check.

I continued to be depressed due to the fact that nothing was working.

I am seeing a therapist.

But on Tuesday I got suspended indefinitely from school, to be re-evaluated in August.

Their reason?

I worry my friends and it distracts them. The police officer I met with at one point forbid me from talking to them when I was scared or hurting anymore.

I informed my friends of this and got various responses ranging from “Fuck them” to “Hell no” to “I don’t care”.

Now to actually answer your question.

You wanna know what is wrong with our society today?

CPS listens to parents over children, even when the kids have evidence.

Depression and suicidal thoughts and anxiety is considered toxic and bad and a thing to be ashamed of.

That’s what’s fucking wrong.

Thank you all for supporting me through this, and for recognizing and spreading awareness that there is a serious issue with our society believing that things like depression, anxiety, or suicidal thoughts are something we should be embarrassed about, something that should be suffered through silently. Because nobody, not a single person, should ever have to fight through anything alone.

EDIT #2: 8/27/18

So the situation right now is this;

I left and went to a wilderness program for three months in an attempt to find better ways to handle my anxiety and suicidal-ness. When I came back, and requested to return to my school, I was told that I have yet to gain enough “insight” (whatever that means), and that they will not allow me back this fall. The current plan is for me to return in January, but that too is still up in the air. This fall, I am doing independent study work. What sucks the most right now is the fact that, well, I can’t do any of the stuff that I loved to do through my school. Additionally, I can’t see my friends very often, which sucks even more.

Thank you all for all of the up votes. We’re at over 16K right now, which I think really is amazing. The situation that I have been placed into really is sucky, and sharing it with more people helps to make sure that it does not happen to somebody else.

I didn’t get to go back.

I tried so, so damn hard. I did everything they asked, I got B+’s and A’s for the first time in my life. I worked my ass off, I went to therapists and I learned anxiety coping strategies. I learned how to combat my ADHD and I worked as hard as I could to become someone who could go back to that school.

But the reason I didn’t get to go back was because they felt that it was unhealthy for the community, and while I have made progress, I haven’t made enough progress.

I feel like I’ve lost everything that I was trying so damn hard to achieve. I loved that school with all of my heart. My friends are there. The activities I love to do are there. My freaking life is there.

And now that I’ve been officially told, non-negotiably, that I am never going to be allowed to return…I feel like my freaking life has been destroyed.

Questions: As a conservative, do you feel that Jimmy Carter is a good person?
Answers:
Above photo from Google

Some years ago Jimmy Carter was in our city with the Habitat For Humanity people building some houses. He was staying at the residence at the University close to where I live. I was walking by the residence when coming toward me was Jimmy Carter in long sleeve check shirt and blue jeans. His eyes looked right at me, he gave me that big smile of his and said, “Hello, isn’t this a marvellous day?”

I said giving him a smile back,”Yes, it sure is.” He nodded and we both just kept walking. That’s it, but from those few seconds I felt he was genuine and friendly. I don’t get star struck, I’ve seen a lot of stars in my professional musician days and I always give them their space and don’t bother them unless introduced.

At any rate, Jimmy Carter seemed to be the real thing. Just a down to earth, friendly man who took the time to say hi to me.

Being a Canadian, I don’t know what kind of a President he was. Nice guy though.

Edit: Today, Oct. 1st. 2022, Jimmy Carter celebrated his 98th. birthday.

Questions: How can leftists justify furries? Isn’t this going too far, even for them?
Answers:
What the hell do furries have to do with leftists? Leftism is about fighting for social, political, and economic equality- furries are not a subject that rates significant interest from the Left one way or the other. İt’s like asking what conservatives think about people who eat hotdogs- why should they have any opinion on a more or less apolitical non-issue?

All I know about furries is that they are people who enjoy dressing up as animals and that this is some kind of a sex thing.

I don’t know how it’s a sex thing and I don’t care to know.

As a leftist somewhat on the libertarian side of the Left, I don’t concern myself with what consenting adults do in their private spaces. It’s simply none of my business.

In other words, I feel no need to either “justify” or “condemn” things that have nothing at all to do with me and cause nobody any harm. Why do conservatives care?

As far as I, or anyone else, knows, many conservatives may well also be furries- it’s not a political thing, it’s a sex thing and if years of conservative sex scandal have shown us anything, it’s that right-wingers are pretty much into everything but a bath and the more they publicly scream and rant about “depraved perversions”, the more likely it is they are privately going at them like gangbusters when they think nobody can find out.

So there might be a whole bunch of furry conservatives out there and I couldn’t give a rat’s derriere.

I don’t care what anybody is into as long as it is fully consensual. I might find a lot of it weird or totally icky but as long as I don’t have to participate, it really does not concern me.

He meant it. He proved it. His legacy was written in blood.

46 years later, after killing 6 million people, Stalin laid in his bed dying.

Stalin’s personal physician was unavailable. Why? Because he was in a dungeon being tortured — for having suggested Stalin didn’t look well and needed rest.

This is the legacy of Russia’s leadership: savage paranoia and power consolidation. Imprisonment for doing your job.

When Stalin’s security guards found him unconscious, they were too afraid to call for help. Decision-making was too centralized. They feared Stalin would wake up and realize they’d called for help without his permission.

So at that funeral, perhaps Stalin spoke more honestly than he even realized.

Questions: If not Nehruvian socialism, then in which way would have right-wing Indians love to see India during its initial period, post-independence?
Answers:
In 1947, India had 3 choices to develop.

The Gandhian one was to develop India from its villages — focusing on agriculture, irrigation, developing lakes, small industries etc.
The Patel-Rajaji one was to develop India through its entrepreneurs and traders encouraging them to build great enterprises. Indian trading houses like the Birlas were quite critical to British logistics in the World Wars.
Nehruvian model was to develop through large public enterprises including IITs and large steel plants.

As Gandhi and Patel died early, and Rajaji losing out of favor with other Congressmen (for showing faults in the Quit Indian movement) Nehruvian model won out.

Nehruvian model was headline grabbing — big dams, big steel plants and big colleges, however these big things floated in an unsupported way.

There was no big push in farm productivity and agriculture languishes in the same state it was 70 years ago. While our peers in 1947 have mastered agriculture and graduated the farmers to factories, we still are figuring out basic agriculture.

Because of the failure to execute agricultural reforms, Naxal movement picked up across India at the end of the Nehru period and continues to trouble to this day. Nehruvian big industry-big dam stuff didn’t really touch most of the Indians.

While Nehru gave an impetus to build the IITs, there was no push to improve the quality of primary and secondary schools that can educate the students to go to the IITs. Schools for the poor India continues to be poor which forced the government to put band-aid such as reservation. If the poor people were educated as well as rich people in the government schools, we might need reservation at all.

With just 400 million people at the time of independence and millions of educated Congress volunteers available, Nehru could have had a massive project to make India 100% literate in just 1 year. If each congress worker had taught a class of 30–40 poor people that was definitely possible. It was not done. Nehru skipped all the basics.

While we built the big hospitals like AIIMS where the politicians can go for getting cured, there was nothing done to rural healthcare. Mao built an amazing network for foot doctors to drastically improve healthcare quality in China. Nehru did nothing like that in his 17 years rule. Life expectancy of Indians continue to be among the poorest.

While the Japanese and Germans recovering from the WW2 unleashed the power of their entrepreneurs [Hitachi, Toyota, Mitsubishi, BMW, Daimler etc] Indian entrepreneurs were shackled with more regulations and taxes. Entrepreneurs could have made government’s job of economic growth much easier, but their hands were tied from the back.

I accept we have the benefit of hindsight and Nehru did have to take a lot of challenges. But, it is impossible not to compare India with its peers including China and Indonesia — both of whom were poorer and large. If Nehru had better economic advisors and a senior leader like Gandhi to keep him in check, India could have progressed much better. No other major country is still looking at its basics such as literacy, electricity, running water and toilets — these many decades after independence.

I regard all of them cut from the same cloth now

So I focus mainly on writing about China, Russia and the few nations that in my opinion are better than the so called poisonous and misguided democracies

Of course being an Indian, if India does do something well, I would praise the people involved

Questions: Would it be possible for Biden, without the support of Congress, to do some type of "Lend-Lease" to Ukraine until Congress gets its act together, or perhaps the 2025 Congress?
Answers:
Interesting question.

One that got me to do a little homework.

And there I found that Lend-Lease provided weapons to be used for free until returned or destroyed.

Most of what was provided fell into the latter bucket, obviously, but apparently a few ships were sent back. Some other equipment was sold to the UK, at a greatly reduced price. And they didn’t finish paying the bill until 2006.

So basically what we’re talking about is arming Ukraine by Executive Order.

Therefore it certainly seems there is precedent for doing this, though Congress would undoubtedly raise holy hell if Biden tried.

But here’s the thing: the money we sent to Ukraine is the best investment we’ve ever made. Ukraine is fighting and dying, while we sit comfortably back watching a global adversary being diminished at no risk to us. Russia has lost 87% of its active-duty troops — more than 300,000 men — and 2/3 of its tanks. That rips a massive hole in Putin’s opium dream of bringing the Soviet Union back together, something we haven’t managed to do on our own.

Moreover the majority money allocated is spent in the US. In the beginning we were sending outdated and surplus items, and then replenishing them with the Ukraine aid funds — thus creating high-paying manufacturing jobs for Americans. We’ve basically cleaned out the closet at this point, but we’re still generating economic benefits at home.

No matter what Moronic Taylor Greene says.

If we didn’t help, Russia would likely overpower Ukraine — not least because they no longer have us to fear. Putin is already threatening Poland, a NATO ally. If he made good on that threat, we would have no choice but to send troops to fight the Russians.

This way is better, at least for us.

Finally, China’s Xi is looking at all of this, and feeding it into his calculations on whether to make a move on Taiwan. Here, too, we have treaty obligations to observe.

So THE DUMBEST THING WE COULD POSSIBLY DO is cut off aid to Ukraine.

Which is exactly why this trump-controlled do-nothing Congress is hoping to do exactly that.

Questions: Why would you boycott a business for their political views. Don't we all have a right to choose?
Answers:

I was in one of those focus panels once, and one thing that they wanted us to discuss was how we viewed the ethics of a business. One guy had an interesting bit of information: he had read a survey where they had found that all respondents had at some point chosen not to buy something from a business due to some ethical consideration. It was a proper, statistical investigation with some 1,500 respondents. And “all respondents” doesn’t mean “100% with rounding”—it meant every single one of them.

If McDonald’s ever does something ethically questionable, and 10 million people on their own decide, just once, the next time they feel like a burger, that nah, I’ll go to Burger King instead, that’s 10 million Big Macs that aren’t being sold. Sure, it’s not going to bring them down, but that’s 40 million bucks they just said no to, so it’s not to be sneezed at, either.

You can vote with your feet. Vote to support a business that does things you like, and not to support a business that does things you dislike.

That’s what “a right to choose” means.

I don’t think I want to be driving in a car without gas or without brakes.

Questions: Is there a point where you personally would be able to set aside your personal political views and listen to someone from the "other side" with an open mind, or are you afraid they might change your current way of thinking?
Answers:
I do this all the time, but there’s a fundamental problem with people who frame the question as you have done. Almost invariably, when uttered this way, “open mind” means “agree with me”. I cannot tell you how many times I’ve listened to people lay out their arguments, thought it over, and concluded that they’re still wrong, only to have them turn around and declare that I’m being close-minded.

Note that these fellows are almost never willing to consider my position on the issue.

Contrariwise, when I ask someone to listen with an open mind, I’m not asking you to agree with me, though I hope you will. I’m asking you to listen to my side well enough to understand my position, even if you still disagree with me.

I’ve had quite a few such discussions with Anthony Zarrella about various philosophical and moral issues, as well as Eric Lowe about some of the same, as well as historical and fencing matters, and with other people. Sometimes they convince me they’re right, sometimes I convince them I am, sometimes not, but invariably they at least understand my position and can articulate what it is, and largely why I think this way, even if we still end up disagreeing.

But these days I kinda hate the term “open mind” because of how often what the asker really means is “just shut up and agree with me”.

Questions: Why does Morgan Freeman not want a Black History Month?
Answers:
I think what Freeman worries about is what many of us worry about with the popularity of “diversity” ideals: division.

And by division, I don’t mean a military divide from violence, or an ideological divide from beliefs, I mean a cultural divide.

Look at this picture:

What do you see?

Some would say that they see a lot of famous black Americans.

What Morgan Freeman is trying to say is that we should be seeing a bunch of famous Americans. They don’t have to be made distinct from others by their race.

I can understand his concern. Sometimes, the “diversity” shtick can give the impression that somehow black history in America is distinct from American history, that black Americans are different than “regular” Americans.

I don’t care for that. As far as I’m concerned, Martin Luther King Jr., Jackie Robinson, Harriet Tubman, and others were famous Americans and do not have to be made distinct from other famous Americans by the color of their skin. There are no “regular” Americans. We are Americans regardless of our skin color.

Don’t misunderstand me as saying Black History Month is wrong. I understand the sentiment behind it, that after so long ignoring the history of Americans who are black, we want to highlight the stories that we never heard.

But if we continue to highlight these stories as if they are somehow separate from other great American stories about white Americans, what message are we sending?

Frankly, we’re continuing to emphasize this notion that an “American” is a white male and American history is about white males, as opposed to black history and the history of women. That’s not a healthy mindset. That’s a divisive mindset.

The story of Martin Luther King Jr. is as much American history as the story of George Washington. And you don’t have to be black to celebrate MLK’s history any more than you have to be white to celebrate Washington’s history. They are both parts of our history.

That’s what Morgan Freeman is getting at. We have a shared history, however ugly it may have been at times. And rather than try and draw a distinction between our histories based on our race, we should recognize our shared history.
